channel.title: Culture Insight
channel.itunes:subtitle: Bringing Ideas to Light
channel.itunes:author: Simply Charly
channel.itunes:summary: Welcome to Culture Insight presented by SimplyCharly.com. These are conversations with authors and experts who have given us insights into those individuals who have influenced our culture and enriched our lives. Look for our Podcast in the iTunes Music Store
channel.description: These are conversations with authors and experts who have given us insights into those individuals who have influenced our culture and enriched our lives. Look for our Podcast in the iTunes Music Store.

item.title: Paul Israel On Thomas Alva Edison
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: Paul Israel is an historian of technology who serves as the Directorand General Editor of the multivolume documentary edition of theThomas Edison Papers at Rutgers University
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul Israel is an historian of technology who serves as the Directorand General Editor of the multivolume documentary edition of theThomas Edison Papers at Rutgers University
item.itunes:summary: Paul Israel is an historian of technology who serves as the Directorand General Editor of the multivolume documentary edition of theThomas Edison Papers at Rutgers University

item.title: Paul Muldoon on W.B. Yeats
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: Paul Muldoon is the author of numerous books of poetry, including the Pulitzer Prize-winning Moy Sand and Gravel. He is a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul Muldoon is the author of numerous books of poetry, including the Pulitzer Prize-winning Moy Sand and Gravel. He is a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He teaches creative writing at Princeton University and was formerly professor of poetry at Oxford University.
item.itunes:summary: Paul Muldoon is the author of numerous books of poetry, including the Pulitzer Prize-winning Moy Sand and Gravel. He is a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He teaches creative writing at Princeton University and was formerly professor of poetry at Oxford University.

item.title: Rebecca Goldstein on Kurt Gödel
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: Rebecca Goldstein is the author Incompleteness: The Proof and Paradox of Kurt Gödel and most recently, Betraying Spinoza: The Renegade Jew Who Gave Us Modernity. She is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and has received many awards for her fiction and scholarship, including a John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation Fellowship.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rebecca Goldstein is the author Incompleteness: The Proof and Paradox of Kurt Gödel and most recently, Betraying Spinoza: The Renegade Jew Who Gave Us Modernity. She is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and has received many awards for her fiction and scholarship, including a John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation Fellowship.
item.itunes:summary: Rebecca Goldstein is the author Incompleteness: The Proof and Paradox of Kurt Gödel and most recently, Betraying Spinoza: The Renegade Jew Who Gave Us Modernity. She is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and has received many awards for her fiction and scholarship, including a John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation Fellowship.

item.title: John Heiss on Igor Stravinsky
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: John Heiss is an active composer, conductor, flutist, and teacher. He is the Director of the Contemporary Ensemble at New England Conservatory, where he teaches in the flute, chamber music, compositio
item.itunes:subtitle: John Heiss is an active composer, conductor, flutist, and teacher. He is the Director of the Contemporary Ensemble at New England Conservatory, where he teaches in the flute, chamber music, compositio
item.itunes:summary: John Heiss is an active composer, conductor, flutist, and teacher. He is the Director of the Contemporary Ensemble at New England Conservatory, where he teaches in the flute, chamber music, composition, music history and music theory departments. His works have been performed worldwide, receiving premieres by Boston Musica Viva, Collage New Music, the Da Capo Chamber Players, and Tanglewood Festival Orchestra among others. He joins us on this program to discuss the life and work of Russian composer Igor Stravinsky.

item.title: Alan Lightman on Albert Einstein
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: Alan Lightman is a novelist, essayist, physicist, and educator. He is Adjunct Professor of Humanities and formerly senior lecturer in Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His novels
item.itunes:subtitle: Alan Lightman is a novelist, essayist, physicist, and educator. He is Adjunct Professor of Humanities and formerly senior lecturer in Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His novels
item.itunes:summary: Alan Lightman is a novelist, essayist, physicist, and educator. He is Adjunct Professor of Humanities and formerly senior lecturer in Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His novels include Einstein's Dreams, which has been translated into more than thirty languages, and The Diagnosis, which was a National Book Award finalist in Fiction in 2000. He joins us on this program to discuss the life and work of Albert Einstein.

item.title: Gay Talese on Ernest Hemingway and Writing
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: American author Gay Talese is the bestselling author of eleven books. He was a reporter for the New York Times from 1956 to 1965, and since then he has written for the Times, Esquire, The New Yorker,
item.itunes:subtitle: American author Gay Talese is the bestselling author of eleven books. He was a reporter for the New York Times from 1956 to 1965, and since then he has written for the Times, Esquire, The New Yorker,
item.itunes:summary: American author Gay Talese is the bestselling author of eleven books. He was a reporter for the New York Times from 1956 to 1965, and since then he has written for the Times, Esquire, The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and other national publications. His groundbreaking article "Frank Sinatra Has a Cold" was named the "best story Esquire ever published," and he was credited by Tom Wolfe with the creation of an inventive form of nonfiction writing called "The New Journalism." Talese joins us on this program to share his insights into Ernest Hemingway and on his own craft as a writer.

item.title: Janna Levin on Kurt Godel
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: Janna Levin is a Professor of Physics and Astronomy at Barnard College of Columbia University. Her scientific research concerns the Early Universe, Chaos, and Black Holes. Her second book a novel,
item.itunes:subtitle: Janna Levin is a Professor of Physics and Astronomy at Barnard College of Columbia University. Her scientific research concerns the Early Universe, Chaos, and Black Holes. Her second book a novel,
item.itunes:summary: Janna Levin is a Professor of Physics and Astronomy at Barnard College of Columbia University. Her scientific research concerns the Early Universe, Chaos, and Black Holes. Her second book a novel, A Madman Dreams of Turing Machines won the PEN/Bingham Fellowship for Writers that "honors an exceptionally talented fiction writer whose debut work...represents distinguished literary achievement..." She joins us today to discuss the life and work of logician Kurt Godel.

item.title: James Flannery on W.B. Yeats
item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.description: Singer, scholar, stage director, producer, lecturer, teacher and cultural activist, James Flannery is the Winship Professor of Arts and Humanities at Emory University. A specialist in the dramatic wor
item.itunes:subtitle: Singer, scholar, stage director, producer, lecturer, teacher and cultural activist, James Flannery is the Winship Professor of Arts and Humanities at Emory University. A specialist in the dramatic wor
item.itunes:summary: James Flannery, Winship Professor of Arts and Humanities at Emory University, joins us on this program to discuss all things Yeats.

item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.title: Kenneth Frampton on Le Corbusier
item.description: On this program we talk with Kenneth Frampton, Ware Professor of Architecture at Columbia University, and the author of several books including Modern Architecture: A Critical History, Labour, Work an
item.itunes:subtitle: On this program we talk with Kenneth Frampton, Ware Professor of Architecture at Columbia University, and the author of several books including Modern Architecture: A Critical History, Labour, Work an
item.itunes:summary: On this program we talk with Kenneth Frampton, Ware Professor of Architecture at Columbia University, and the author of several books including Modern Architecture: A Critical History, Labour, Work and Architecture, and a book about the Swiss born architect Le Corbusier who became a French citizen in his 30's. Le Corbusier was one of the pioneers of modern architecture. He was also an urban planner, painter, sculptor and modern furniture designer.

item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.title: Frank Wilczek on Albert Einstein
item.description: Herman Feshbach Professor of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Frank Wilczek is a theoretical physicist who won the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physics for a discovery in the world of quar
item.itunes:subtitle: Herman Feshbach Professor of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Frank Wilczek is a theoretical physicist who won the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physics for a discovery in the world of quar
item.itunes:summary: Herman Feshbach Professor of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Frank Wilczek is a theoretical physicist who won the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physics for a discovery in the world of quarks, the building blocks of the atomic nucleus. His latest book is The Lightness of Being: Mass, Ether and the Unification of Forces. He joins us on this program to share his insights on Albert Einstein and on his own groundbreaking work.

item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.title: Jack Sullivan on Alfred Hitchcock
item.description: Jack Sullivan is a literary scholar and professor of English at Rider University. He has published several books including New World Symphonies: How American Culture Changed European Music and most re;
item.itunes:subtitle: Jack Sullivan is a literary scholar and professor of English at Rider University. He has published several books including New World Symphonies: How American Culture Changed European Music and most re
item.itunes:summary: Jack Sullivan is a literary scholar and professor of English at Rider University. He has published several books including New World Symphonies: How American Culture Changed European Music and most recently Hitchcock's Music. He joins us on this program to share his insight into Alfred Hitchcock and the role which music played in his films.

item.itunes:author: Simply Charly
item.title: John Darnton on Charles Darwin
item.description: John Darnton is a Pulitzer prize winning reporter and best selling novelist who has worked for The New York Times for over 40 years. His many books include Neanderthal, The Experiment, Mind Catcher, T
item.itunes:subtitle: John Darnton is a Pulitzer prize winning reporter and best selling novelist who has worked for The New York Times for over 40 years. His many books include Neanderthal, The Experiment, Mind Catcher, T
item.itunes:summary: John Darnton is a Pulitzer prize winning reporter and best selling novelist who has worked for The New York Times for over 40 years. His many books include Neanderthal, The Experiment, Mind Catcher, The Darwin Conspiracy and most recently Black & White and Dead All Over Again. He joins us on this program to share his insight into Charles Darwin's life and his controversial theory of evolution.
